label: Giacomo Medici
description: Italian antiquities dealer active from the 1960s. Convicted in 2005 of receiving stolen goods and conspiracy to traffic. Central node in one of the largest illicit antiquities networks ever uncovered.

label: Robert Hecht
description: US-based antiquities dealer who purchased material from Medici from 1967 onward. Believed to have acquired the Euphronios krater from Medici in 1971 and sold it to the Metropolitan Museum.

label: Christian Boursaud
description: Geneva-based partner of Medici from 1978. Consigned Medici's material to Sotheby's London and co-founded the Hydra Gallery in 1983. Partnership dissolved in 1986.

label: Robin Symes
description: London-based antiquities dealer who developed commercial relations with Medici by the late 1980s.

label: Frieda Tchacos
description: Dealer with commercial relations with Medici by the late 1980s. Part of the network identified through the Freeport evidence.

label: Nikolas Koutoulakis
description: Paris-based antiquities dealer connected to Medici's supply network by the late 1980s.

label: Ali Aboutaam
description: Geneva-based dealer and brother of Hicham Aboutaam. Developed commercial relations with Medici by the late 1980s.

label: Hicham Aboutaam
description: New York-based dealer and brother of Ali Aboutaam. Part of Medici's downstream distribution network.

label: Marion True
description: Former antiquities curator at the J. Paul Getty Museum. Her prosecution was triggered by evidence recovered during the Medici investigation.

label: Sotheby's London
description: Throughout the 1980s Medici was the source of more consignments to Sotheby's London than any other vendor. Material delivered from Geneva by courier.

label: Editions Services
description: Geneva-based company purchased by Medici in 1986 to continue consigning material to Sotheby's after his split with Boursaud.

label: Hydra Gallery
description: Gallery opened in Geneva in 1983 by Medici and Boursaud. Sold the Onesimos kylix fragments to the Getty in 1985 using a false provenance.

label: J. Paul Getty Museum
description: Purchased the Onesimos kylix from Hydra Gallery in 1985 for $100000. Returned the kylix to Italy in 1999 and later the Aphrodite of Morgantina.

label: Metropolitan Museum of Art
description: Acquired the Euphronios krater in 1972 via Hecht. The krater was displayed for over 30 years before being returned to Italy in 2008.

label: Cleveland Museum of Art
description: Among the museums found to have acquired material ultimately sourced from Medici's network.

label: Boston Museum of Fine Arts
description: Among the museums found to have acquired material ultimately sourced from Medici's network.

label: Euphronios Krater
description: Illegally excavated near Cerveteri c.1971. Believed purchased by Medici from tombaroli then sold to Hecht then to the Met for $1 million. Returned to Italy 2008.

label: Onesimos Kylix
description: Fragments sold by Hydra Gallery to the Getty in 1985 for $100000 with a false provenance citing the fictitious Zbinden collection. Returned to Italy 1999.

label: Geneva Freeport
description: Medici's five-room storage space raided 13 September 1995. Found to contain 3800 artefacts and over 4000 Polaroid photographs documenting looted objects.

label: Carabinieri TPC
description: Italy's cultural property protection unit. Coordinated with Swiss police on the 1995 Freeport raid. Recovered the organigram and thousands of Polaroids.

label: San Saba Sarcophagus
description: Sarcophagus stolen from the church of San Saba in Rome. Recognized in a 1995 Sotheby's catalogue consigned by Editions Services. Triggered the Medici investigation.

label: Shelby White & Leon Levy
description: New York-based private collectors identified as recipients of material ultimately sourced from Medici.

label: Fleischman Collection
description: Lawrence and Barbara Fleischman were private collectors identified as recipients of material ultimately sourced from Medici.

label: Antiquaria Romana
description: Gallery opened by Medici in Rome in 1968. Closed in 1978 when Medici moved his operations to Switzerland.
